comments.message: Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased
Change has been successfully merged by Troy Ronda

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-16559] Support Go plugins in fabric-cli

This patch adds support for Go plugins as fabric-cli plugins. A Go
plugin implements a factory that returns a cobra.Command. The returned
command is added as a sub-command of the main fabric command.

At load time, the binary specified in the plugin.yaml file is first
loaded as a Go plugin. If this fails then it reverts to the current
behavior.

Signed-off-by: Bob Stasyszyn <Bob.Stasyszyn@securekey.com>
Change-Id: I27bb663c4ece72a81cbbf277ced1f0e92e3d1033
data.subject: [FAB-16559] Support Go plugins in fabric-cli

comments.message: Change has been successfully merged by Troy Ronda

[FAB-16563] Use latest SDK and fabric-protos-go

Point to the latest fabric-sdk-go which uses the protos from
hyperledger/fabric-protos-go.

Signed-off-by: Bob Stasyszyn <Bob.Stasyszyn@securekey.com>
Change-Id: I33d0254386116f7f9981628221e9f9d76c083b52
data.subject: [FAB-16563] Use latest SDK and fabric-protos-go

comments.message: Change has been successfully merged by Troy Ronda

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-16660] Plugin commands not respecting home flag

The plugin directory is set in the plugin commands before the
--home flag is processed and therefore the default directory
is always used. This patch defers the initialization until
execution time.

Signed-off-by: Bob Stasyszyn <Bob.Stasyszyn@securekey.com>
Change-Id: I93c7a5ba0f9cf9dee87fc532c7c138cb11fc57fd

comments.message: The initialization of the handler might be better suited as a `Complete` method.  This would be more consistent with the pattern established in other commands.

data.subject: [FAB-16660] Plugin commands not respecting home flag

comments.message:
Patch Set 2:

(23 comments)

Thanks for getting this started!

My biggest problem is with the name fabctl (of course! ;-). Why not sticking to fabric in accordance with the design doc? It's only one character longer, much easier to remember, and a lot less prone to typos. If you really want a shorter name I would go with fab but I think explicit names are better.

Otherwise, I don't see the point of having the directory cmd. I suggest moving factl (i.e. fabric ;-) one level up. The simpler the hierarchy the better.
The same is true for pkg. For what it's worth its generic name is an indication that it is not really meaningful.

Other comments inlined.

I like the general approach with the plugins.

Patch Set 3:

> (23 comments)
 > 
 > Thanks for getting this started!
 > 
 > My biggest problem is with the name fabctl (of course! ;-). Why not
 > sticking to fabric in accordance with the design doc? It's only one
 > character longer, much easier to remember, and a lot less prone to
 > typos. If you really want a shorter name I would go with fab but I
 > think explicit names are better.
 > 
 > Otherwise, I don't see the point of having the directory cmd. I
 > suggest moving factl (i.e. fabric ;-) one level up. The simpler the
 > hierarchy the better.
 > The same is true for pkg. For what it's worth its generic name is
 > an indication that it is not really meaningful.
 > 
 > Other comments inlined.
 > 
 > I like the general approach with the plugins.

I am not biased toward any name.  I went ahead and switched it back to "fabric".

It is common practice with Golang to divide code into cmd and pkg directories.  Many open source projects follow this structure (https://github.com/golang-standards/project-layout).

If we assume there will only ever be one cli binary in this repo, I would suggest: "github.com/hyperledger/fabric-cli/cmd" instead of "github.com/hyperledger/fabric-cli/cmd/fabric" and "github.com/hyperledger/fabric-cli/fabric".

Thanks for the pointer. I have seen this layout before but didn't know there was an effort to make it some kind of a standard. Fine then but, I like the idea of going with just cmd, instead of cmd/fabric. I don't expect to have more than one command, do you? 

And according to this "standard" pkg is supposed to hold stuff that can be used outside of the project. Do you think that's true for what we have in there?? It doesn't seem like it to me.

Other than that I'm good with where this is going. :-)

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-13891] Create initial implementation using cobra

Created intial cli using cobra.  Examples of both built-in commands and plugins are provided.

Change-Id: Icc7f0a6b0dc09c21a30148c5f37ae65c746e8647
Signed-off-by: Brian Buchanan <bpbuch@gmail.com>

comments.message:
I think you either need to add some output messages or remove the silencing @ so the user knows what is happening.
As it stands, typing "make" shows no signs of doing anything, which is confusing.
I'm in favor of simply removing the @ signs.
I think that's the wrong word to use. One might expect more than is provided. I suggest: interact with.
as noted in the general comment, I think this should be named fabric
I think this should say "Built-in commands".
this seems to be a bit of an oversimplification. The home test plugin shows that one may have to compile it too, right?

This seems to be saying that either: 1) built-in commands (the commands themselves) can be expanded with plugins, 2) built-in commands are plugins, and therefore could be replaced. My understanding is neither is true, is it?
So, I suggest saying something like "The list of commands can be expanded via plugins.

This is an oversimplification for the current state. In the future, there could be an "install" field in the yaml file that would allow the developer of the plugin to stream line this at the time of plugin installation.
I don't think we need this to be in subdir. Util packages are considered to be an anti-pattern for that matter...
this is at odd with what's set just above :-)
I assume using a symlink is a temporary hack, isn't it?
Same comment as for the other Makefile. Remove the @ signs so that the user knows what's going on.
This command fails unless cobra is locally installed because although it is vendored into the main dir, it doesn't get picked up here.
this got me confused, I suggest changing to "command" or fabric command.
this needs to be changed to Fprintln

data.subject: [FAB-13891] Create initial implementation using cobra

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(16 comments)

This is going in the right direction but the change in the way the env and defaults are handled leads to a plugin execution failure unless FABRIC_HOME is set in the user's env:
$ ./bin/fabric home
Error: fork/exec /plugins/home/bin/home: no such file or directory

$ FABRIC_HOME=~/.fabric ./bin/fabric home
/Users/lehors/.fabric

Patch Set 3:

> This is going in the right direction but the change in the way the
 > env and defaults are handled leads to a plugin execution failure
 > unless FABRIC_HOME is set in the user's env:
 > $ ./bin/fabric home
 > Error: fork/exec /plugins/home/bin/home: no such file or directory
 > 
 > $ FABRIC_HOME=~/.fabric ./bin/fabric home
 > /Users/lehors/.fabric

Nice catch. This was an oversight on my part.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

A suggestion about mocks for future, Brian... looks good otherwise.
Change has been successfully merged by Arnaud J Le Hors

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-13945] Create profile management commands

Implement profile management commands using a config yaml file in
the home directory.

Unit tests need to be refactored to match the patterns found in the
Fabric project in a future CR.

Change-Id: I6a849968b470165251dfc81bed37582650e880da
Signed-off-by: Brian Buchanan <bpbuch@gmail.com>

comments.message: this is not the right comment
I think it'd make sense to make the new profile active if there is no active profile, as it's the case with the first profile.

If the intent is for the profile to actually be deleted through this command I think it would be better to call it that: Delete.
Remove makes it sound like it is merely removed from the config but can still live elsewhere and possibly added back.
It would be good to have a list command as well.
Is there a strong reason for this? It does seem like a nice safeguard to have but then we would have to have a -f/--force option and I'm not sure this is really worth it.
I think it'd make sense to show the active profile by default but allow specifying a profile name to show as well.
As things stand I think this should rather read something like "no profile currently active"
This relies on FABRIC_HOME having been set in the environment.
Please, can we use os.TempDir() or ioutil.TempDir() instead?
From what I understand this is still required because the execution of a plugin command depends on it to set the correct command path. See related comment in fabric.go
you need to reset cmd.active if the profile that is deleted is the active one.
It'd be nice to identify if a profile is active with something like "foo (active)" or "foo (in use)".
with profilename being optional this should read "[profilename]"
Perhaps consider using "counterfeiter" instead of handcoding mocks (the UT revision you mentioned in Description feels a perfect time for the consideration)

data.subject: [FAB-13945] Create profile management commands

comments.message:
Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Looks good overall. Just a nit.
Otherwise, the changes include some small changes to the code beyond the test harness, it would be good to document in the commit message what the changes are about.
Change has been successfully merged by Arnaud J Le Hors

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-14276] Use Ginkgo and Gomega to drive unit tests

Converted test cases to use Ginkgo and Gomega and increased overall code
coverage. Also, replaced mocks with counterfeiter fakes.

Command implementation structs have been exported to be accessible in the
test packages.  This allows the tests to mock the APIs used.

Updated State Street copyright header.

Change-Id: I446b56fa2b1a840c0a7d833e944d149b3dc43a14
Signed-off-by: Brian Buchanan <bpbuch@gmail.com>

comments.message: I agree it is worth explicitly stating that "no plugins currently exist" because producing no output at all can leave the user wondering what happened but, don't raise it as an error. There is nothing wrong with not having any plugins installed and the list command actually succeeds.

data.subject: [FAB-14276] Use Ginkgo and Gomega to drive unit tests

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-14515] Encapsulate Fabric GO SDK

Encapsulated the various clients provided by the Fabric Go SDK.  The
encapsulation will provide a starting point for potential future
implementation of longer living clients.

Implemented profile to SDK config transformation using templates.  The
template serves as a dynamic way to generate sdk config yaml.  The
transformation takes place when any SDK client is instantiated.

Generated mocks for SDK clients.

Change-Id: I10586dca42c111be38a5279b439446f0f998bf05
Signed-off-by: Brian Buchanan <bpbuch@gmail.com>

comments.message: ledger client - being pedantic, but none of the others are capitalized
any plans on using go mod instead of dep? Go SDK now supports go mod.
probably use 'newSDKClient' to follow the same pattern as in: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30555/2/pkg/fabric/factory.go#34

channel 'SDK' configs are not loaded dynamically? 

if so, then the channel client will 'only' be creating new channels? 

see a Go SDK example of channel config section:
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/master/test/fixtures/config/config_e2e.yaml#L109
note: the latest (from master) includes module definitions in the SDK project (alpha5 did not).
FYI: I'm looking at moving this module definition up a level to encompass the entire third_party fabric directory and children.

data.subject: [FAB-14515] Encapsulate Fabric GO SDK

comments.message:
Patch Set 3:

I fully support the move but this requires installing gobin: 'we need to bootstrap the process by installing gobin "by hand"' https://github.com/myitcv/gobin/wiki/FAQ#hang-on-isnt-gobin-a-tool-too-catch-22

So, I suggest adding to the installation instructions in the README this first step:
$ GO111MODULE=off go get -u github.com/myitcv/gobin

Successfully tested with "GO111MODULE=on make test" and "GO111MODULE=on make lint"
Change has been successfully merged by Arnaud J Le Hors

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-15125] Improve profile usability

Convert profile storage from an array to a map.  This makes accessing
the active profile easier by reducing profile lookup complexity.

Refactored profile commands to use the profile map.

Omitted empty profile details to reduce config file size.

Change-Id: Ic6e545a716850abad31c104e547785913d9b2e5e
Signed-off-by: Brian Buchanan <bpbuch@gmail.com>
data.subject: [FAB-15125] Improve profile usability

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

I have to admit not to be familiar with this format - the uppercased arguments. Is that a new trend?

Patch Set 1:

> I have to admit not to be familiar with this format - the
 > uppercased arguments. Is that a new trend?

My memory served me wrong with other CLIs.  I think it should remain lowercased with angle brackets denoting required arguments.  I do still want to add a delimiter. It looks like `-` might be more common than `_`.
Change has been successfully merged by Arnaud J Le Hors

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-15195] Update command argument syntax

Updated arguments to be use lowercase characters delimited by `-`.  Angle
brackets are used to show required arguments.  Squared brackets are used to
show optional arguments.

Change-Id: Ie2138aeb6f109ac2476946a891f07b58da0cdecf
Signed-off-by: Brian Buchanan <bpbuch@gmail.com>
data.subject: [FAB-15195] Update command argument syntax

comments.message: Change has been successfully merged by Arnaud J Le Hors

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-14959] Add Channel Commands

Implemented core channel commands(create|update|join|list|config).  The
commands should follow a rule such that the active profile context drives
the commands unless otherwise specified. Channel commands ignore the channel
context field since operations are done in the context of a peer.

Flag overrides need to be implemented to allow "on the fly" context switches.

Change-Id: I73a3c127e1f51612aca6ef38d8d6147279419be7
Signed-off-by: Brian Buchanan <bpbuch@gmail.com>

comments.message: Same question as in update.go (re: switching profiles).
Same question as in update.go (re: switching profiles).
Same question as in update.go (re: switching profiles).
Same question as in update.go (re: switching profiles).

What happens to c.ResourceManagement when profiles change?

(since c.Profile is an argument used to create c.ResourceManagement)

It is unlikely that profile would change during the same execution of the command, but it is possible depending on how to command is implemented.  Profile overrides/flags would need to be processed before creating the client.  In the event that the profile changed post client initialization, the client would not be updated.

data.subject: [FAB-14959] Add Channel Commands

comments.message: Change has been successfully merged by Arnaud J Le Hors

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

First, let me say that I think this is a good move so you don't think the rest of my comments means I disagree with the direction. :-) But I do have a few highlevel comments I want to share from a first cursory review.

Is there any actual value in keeping the config command level? It seems to just lead to unnecessary typing to me. And it forces you to have longer subcommand names to disambiguate between context and network commands. I think it would be simpler to just separate the two groups and have: fabric context current|delete|list|set|use and fabric network delete|list|set

And I know you're trying to follow some emerging standard layout for the files hierarchy but I think "cmd/commands/command/base_command.go" exhibits some severe case of stuttering! That's literally 4 levels of variations on "command"...

Finally, it'd be great if you could develop a minimal doc as you go. You can probably just build on the README for now but we should have some minimal doc at least describing succinctly the series of commands one would typically go through. I'd love to be able to help with but I have to admit not to be completely sure how it's supposed to work at this point so it makes it difficult.
But, please, don't let my comments and questions discourage you! Thank you for keeping us moving forward.

Patch Set 1:

> Is there any actual value in keeping the config command level? It
 > seems to just lead to unnecessary typing to me. And it forces you
 > to have longer subcommand names to disambiguate between context and
 > network commands. I think it would be simpler to just separate the
 > two groups and have: fabric context current|delete|list|set|use and
 > fabric network delete|list|set
 
My thought process was that these commands are directly referencing and
manipulating the config file, but I can see the argument to separate them as
they are two different logical entities.  I will separate them.  In the future,
custom help text could help portray that they modify a config.

 > And I know you're trying to follow some emerging standard layout
 > for the files hierarchy but I think "cmd/commands/command/base_command.go"
 > exhibits some severe case of stuttering! That's literally 4 levels
 > of variations on "command"...

The stutter could be reduced a little by moving the base command package to be
a sibling of the commands package (`cmd/commands` and `cmd/command`) or
creating a common/util package.

 > Finally, it'd be great if you could develop a minimal doc as you
 > go. You can probably just build on the README for now but we should
 > have some minimal doc at least describing succinctly the series of
 > commands one would typically go through. I'd love to be able to
 > help with but I have to admit not to be completely sure how it's
 > supposed to work at this point so it makes it difficult.
 > But, please, don't let my comments and questions discourage you!
 > Thank you for keeping us moving forward.

Updating the README is a great idea.  I can see the confusion as a first time
user.

Patch Set 3:

(20 comments)

Thanks for the refactoring. This is definitely simpler. I got some question (my ignorance) and some comments embedded.

Patch Set 4:

(9 comments)

Looking good. A few typos and a couple more suggestions.

Patch Set 5: Verified+1

Looks good! I'll let you remove the extra spaces Troy found and will merge it.
Change has been successfully merged by Arnaud J Le Hors

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-15279] Split Profile to Network/Context

Removed profile in favor of a network and context combination.  Decoupling the
the network configuration from the context allows for easier toggling between
contexts related to the same network.  Network is a direct reference to a SDK
config yaml.  Context is a container for parameters to be used when working
with the SDK clients.

Added config commands to drive network and context configuration.

Added global flags for changing home directory and current context.

Removed the package scoped functions used to create fabric clients.  Package
scoped functions introduce difficulties with testing.  Accessing clients
through the factory allows for mock replacements.

Created base commands to reduce redundancy between commands.  The base
commands are embedded in higher level commands.

Updated README with Getting Started instructions and Network/Context
descriptions.

Change-Id: I7dbafeef1f133cb3c64e9b25e2b274be920b4ab6
Signed-off-by: Brian Buchanan <bpbuch@gmail.com>

comments.message: I think we should rename this ViewCommand and allow one to specify a context name and display its settings so that not merely the current context can be viewed. You can display the current one if no name is specified.

I think if there is a current context and no name is specified we should act on the current context rather than throw an error, although for a destructive method you could insist on the name being specified.

I would prefer to require a name to be specified for destructive commands for now.  It would be frustrating to run `fabric context delete` on accident and then the current context is clobbered.  In the future, I could see the case for a "Are you sure?" type interaction.
I think if there is a current context and no name is specified we should act on the current context rather than throw an error.
It seems like we should check that at least one flag was set or throw an error.

There is a problem with this because this changes the whole context with a new one that merely contains what was set during this invocation. I actually want to be able to set different parts of the context sequentially like:
fabric context set foo --user admin
fabric context set foo --organization myorg

But currently the second call replaces the context with a new one that only contains myorg, throwing away the previous user setting.

Note that this should probably be addressed in SetContext. See related comment there.

Like for context, we should have a View command to display the path of any given network, specified by name. This currently cannot be retrieved in any way it seems other than looking into the configuration file directly.
You don't really mean that, do you? :-)
We also need to check that the path flag has actually been set.
I haven't used cobra in a while so I'm probably missing something but I'm a bit surprised we need to handle this ourselves. Isn't that something cobra normally does??
Unless I missed it, I do not believe cobra supports this style of argument support.  There are various ways to validate args, but not a way to predefine arguments.

While this works it silently drops extra arguments. While not dramatic it would be helpful to throw an error when that happens because otherwise the user may not be aware.
For instance, I once ran: fabric network set foo /tmp/foo which claimed to have succeeded when in fact it had not because due to the missing --path the /tmp/foo was ignored.

This was intentional.  I left this open to allow for handling optional arguments.  In the future, this should probably expose a way to define an argument as `required` or `optional`.  

As for your example, I believe the command should have caught the missing path flag (you made this recommendation in a different comment).
This is the code that should probably be changed. If c.Contexts[name] already exists, its attributes should be preserved if they are not being set in new context.
This should read "its" but it wouldn't hurt to expand to "the config"

I wonder whether this shouldn't be renamed GetCurrentContextNetwork because the current name implies something that doesn't quite exist, at least not directly. At the very least we should make the comments and error messages clearer to help both developers and users know what it is really going on, and how to set the "current network".
no network is set for the current context
Man, I can't believe we all missed that one before! Good catch.
How about calling the ViewCommand at this point? Every time I use set I then call view to actually see the change I made. It'd be nice to have that done automatically.
Same here as for context set, I suggest you run the view command to let the user actually see the result.

data.subject: [FAB-15279] Split Profile to Network/Context

comments.message: Assignee added: Arnaud J Le Hors <lehors@us.ibm.com>
Assignee deleted: Arnaud J Le Hors <lehors@us.ibm.com>

Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

Thanks Brian. It looks good overall except for a few minor errors. However, this depends on the Fabric 1.4 chaincode lifecycle. Shouldn't we go for the Fabric 2.0 instead?

Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

> Thanks Brian. It looks good overall except for a few minor errors. However, this depends on the Fabric 1.4 chaincode lifecycle. Shouldn't we go for the Fabric 2.0 instead?

2.0 chaincode lifecycle support is dependent on the SDK.  Currently, the SDK supports version 1.4.  Should we bypass the SDK temporarily?

Patch Set 3:

It would be wonderful if you wish to contribute the 2.0 lifecycle code to the SDK (as an alternative to bypassing).

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> (3 comments)
> 
> > Thanks Brian. It looks good overall except for a few minor errors. However, this depends on the Fabric 1.4 chaincode lifecycle. Shouldn't we go for the Fabric 2.0 instead?
> 
> 2.0 chaincode lifecycle support is dependent on the SDK.  Currently, the SDK supports version 1.4.  Should we bypass the SDK temporarily?

Patch Set 3:

> It would be wonderful if you wish to contribute the 2.0 lifecycle code to the SDK (as an alternative to bypassing).
> 
> > Patch Set 3:
> > 
> > (3 comments)
> > 
> > > Thanks Brian. It looks good overall except for a few minor errors. However, this depends on the Fabric 1.4 chaincode lifecycle. Shouldn't we go for the Fabric 2.0 instead?
> > 
> > 2.0 chaincode lifecycle support is dependent on the SDK.  Currently, the SDK supports version 1.4.  Should we bypass the SDK temporarily?

That is a great idea Troy.  For the time being, I think we should move forward with this PR as is(only 1.4).  We should probably be able to handle both versions.  We can add 2.0 support as a follow up PR when the SDK is ready.

Patch Set 3: Verified+1 Code-Review+2

Ok, I think that's reasonable.

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-15203] Sort profile list

This changes the "profile list" command so that the profile list is
alphabetically sorted.

Before:
$ bin/fabric profile list
foo
alh
bar (active)

After:
$ bin/fabric profile list
alh
bar (active)
foo

Change-Id: I7541051170068058940a7b6df34f290fe546c4c8
Signed-off-by: Arnaud J Le Hors <lehors@us.ibm.com>
data.subject: [FAB-15203] Sort profile list
